```{r}
#| include: false

library(knitr)
library(rmarkdown)
library(tidyverse)
library(skimr)
library(ggthemes)
library(hrbrthemes)

theme_set(theme_ipsum()+
          theme(strip.background =element_rect(fill="lightgray"),
                axis.title.x  = element_text(angle = 0,
                                            size = rel(1.5),
                                            margin = margin(10,0,0,0)),
                axis.title.y  = element_text(angle = 0,
                                            size = rel(1.5),
                                            margin = margin(0,10,0,0))
                )
          )
```

Let's analyze the `Spotify` data:

```{r}
Spotify <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/spotify_all.csv")
```


```{r}
#| results: asis
rmarkdown::paged_table(Spotify) 
```



## Variable Description for `Spotify` data.frame

The following describes the variables in the `Spotify` data.frame.


- `playlist_name`
Names of playlists

- `pid`
Pid number

- `pos`
Pos number

- `artist_name`
Name of artist

- `track_name`
Name of track

- `duration_ms`
Duration of the song

- `album_name`
Name of the album


## track_name vs. pid

```{r}
ggplot(data = 
         Spotify %>% 
         filter(track_name %in% c("track_name", "pid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = track_name, y = pid, 
                   fill = track_name),
               show.legend = FALSE)

```
